DOC.HEAD: Bush Meets on Military Role in Drug War
DOC.TEXT: President Bush met with Defense Secretary Richard Cheney and Attorney General Dick Thornburgh on Tuesday to weigh a wider role for the military in the war on drugs, administration officials said. The subject of the Oval Office session was a recent Justice Department legal opinion suggesting the U.S. military could legally arrest drug offenders overseas. Bush advocated use of the military for raids on strongholds of drug kingpins during last year's presidential campaign. He hinted at a military role in his Sept. 6 anti-drug speech to the nation, but at the times aides said he did not envision an overseas mission. However, presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said Tuesday's session was ``to sort all this out,'' including possible use of the military to interdict drug traffickers in the source countries. Bush has expressed recent frustration with the increase of drug-related violence in Colombia and with his inability to influence events in Panama. Panamanian strongman Manuel Antonio Noriega is under indictment in Florida on drug trafficking charges. At Tuesday's White House session, Cheney presented a preliminary report on the role of the military in the anti-drug effort to Bush, said White House spokeswoman Alixe Glen. ``A final strategy will be forthcoming,'' she said. White House officials over the weekend acknowledged receiving the Justice Department opinion and said it was being studied. The legal opinion said that the 1878 law which prohibits the military from funtioning as a police agency on U.S. soil has no bearing overseas. The report was written by Assistant Attorney General William P. Barr, head of the Justice Department's office of legal counsel, in November at the behest of the White House. Its existence was disclosed last week. At the Pentagon Tuesday, spokesman Pete Williams said the legal opinion would not automatically mean an expanded military role in the drug war. ``It's a Justice Department option, not a policy,'' he said.
